Were RTI activists not to have been the target of violence in several cases and nine of them not to have been killed in different parts of the country this year, the Centre would not have been forced to consider offering protection to them under the whistleblowers category.

Seven people might not have been killed and 55, including minor children, might not have been injured in two bicycle-bomb blasts in Nalbari, headquarters town of lower Assam's Nalbari district on Sunday morning if police had not suspected that it was the handiwork of ULFA desperate to show its strength after arrests, say police, or if a Caller had not told TV channels that ULFA is not involved in the blasts.
Had the first blast not occurred just near the Nalbari Police Station in the heart of the town around 10 a.m., it wouldn't have injured several people.

Had the massive assembly of market-goers not converged near the injured and the blast aftermaths, a subsequent significantly powerful explosion might not have taken place in close proximity to the initial blast site.

It might not have been the case that the tragic loss of five lives on the spot in the second blast and the severe injuries, including critical ones sustained by over fifty individuals, would have unfolded differently had alternative circumstances been present.

Assuming the caller's allegation was untrue, it would mean the blasts were not orchestrated by vested interests aiming to thwart a fresh initiative by the People��s Committee for Peace Initiative in Assam (PCPIA), which is a coalition of civil society groups striving to facilitate peace dialogue between the ULFA and the government.

Even if the ULFA had not denied it, the police would still have suspected the twin blasts to be the handiwork of the militant outfit, as indicated by a senior police officer, who declined to be quoted on the ground that investigations were still on, when speaking to The Hindu.
It might not have been the case that the two improvised bicycle-bombs would have remained untriggered had it not been for the ULFA's actions.
Were it not for the blasts having been triggered in a public place, the ULFA would not be in a denial mode, nor would it be fearing public outcry against it, he said.

Assuming the movement had not been opposed by others who were bussed in on Sunday, August 17 for a free lunch to participate in a march which occupied Central, thereby undermining their own argument, things might have unfolded differently to not undermine their position.

Were it not for the ongoing stake sale deal between Jet Airways' promoters and Gulf carrier Etihad, it is unlikely that labour unrest would be brewing in the airline, with its engineers not donning black bands to protest an alleged move to freeze salary hikes and pilots not deciding to meet shortly on the same issue.

A section of Jet technicians might not have initiated a 'symbolic' protest by wearing black bands last Friday against the "management's proposed move to freeze wage hike over the next 2-3 years," sources among the agitators here contend, had it not been for the discontent over the wage freeze proposal.

Were it not the case that the fully-armed Naxalites have resorted to such high profile abductions to get their arrested colleagues released, it would not serve as a reminder to the Indian state that they realise it is soft and could be manipulated by such techniques.

Were it not the case that the official claim posits the abductions as stemming from the Naxalites' diminishing support base, this assertion would not serve to distract from the fundamental matter at hand.

It is possible that the two men wouldn't have been arrested for the murder of two ANC branch leaders on the KwaZulu-Natal south coast had it not been for the police actions leading to their capture, as stated on Tuesday.
Assuming the men hadn't been charged, the legal processes concerning their alleged murders would have unfolded differently.

Had the clashes between two rival groups of students on April 30 not occurred, Aligarh Muslim University would not have been closed and consequently wouldn't have needed to reopen on 13th May 2011 03:44 PM.
Were the Proctor not held accountable for the violent incidents, the Teachers' Association would not have commenced an indefinite relay hunger strike from yesterday.

Were it not for those climbers hanging the banner on Lion Rock, people's spirits would not have been boosted, and consequently, the brief duration for which it was displayed would not have ensured its perpetual place in people's hearts.

SCB Medical College and Hospital might not have plunged into a major crisis with the junior doctors turning against senior faculty and college authorities following the arrest of their counterpart for alleged use of force on a journalist recently if the junior doctors hadn't been on strike, thereby preventing the service from being crippled on 28th June 2013 12:07 PM.

Medical services could have continued functioning had the junior doctors not resorted to cease-work agitation demanding removal of the college Dean as well as head of the Medicine Department along with arrest of the journalist , against whom they had lodged a complaint .
Had it not been for the more than 450 junior doctors staying off duty, the functioning of the Departments and critical units would not have been so severely impacted.
It might not have been the case that a PIL was filed in the Orissa High Court appealing for declaring the cease-work illegal had the situation been different.
The petitioner Rohan Mohanty has submitted that hundreds of patients would not have been affected by the junior doctors' strike if they had been directed to join duty immediately.

Had the strike by the locals not occurred, the work on the Kadakaamkunnu railway over bridge would not have been suspended, and thus, it could have continued without interruption from the period it was halted.
Had the work on the bridge not been progressing at a snail's pace, the locals wouldn't have begun agitation since June 16.
Assuming no steps had been taken to prevent the escalation of violence, it's plausible the DGP would not have been able to assert that such measures were underway.
Assuming the police action hadn't occurred, it's plausible that PFI activists wouldn't have organized a subsequent march in the city to protest against it.

Maharashtra��s opposition parties could have possibly supported a reduction in the prison term being served by actor Sanjay Dutt in the 1993 Mumbai serial blasts case if their objection wasn't for relief to him.

Among these was the petition filed on behalf of Kersi Adajania, and it is conceivable that had he not been convicted for helping to melt the AK-56 rifle, which Mr. Dutt had stored in his house, the petition might not have been filed.

Police would not have resorted to tear gas and lathicharge on diamond polishers as mob turned violent at Varachha had the thousands of workers who had queued up outside SDA office to collect forms to waive school fees not created a scenario leading to unrest.

Had the gathering of jobless diamond workers outside the Surat Diamond Association (SDA) office at Varachha on Monday not turned violent, police would not have resorted to baton charge and tear gas shelling against them.
Assuming they had anticipated receiving the forms, the mob might not have resorted to violence and hurling stones at SDA property and vehicles parked outside.

In Khammam on December 15, 2006, the near-total strike could have been averted had the demonstrations not marked the protest against government policies called by the left trade unions against the Centre's economic policies.

Had the employees and workers not been fearful mainly due to the moves of the government, the situation at the Collectorate during the protest involving M. Sudhakar, the Partial in Singareni The Telangana NGOs State associate president who took part, might have unfolded differently.
The government could have experienced a different reaction from the protesters had they not raised slogans against it.

One Charul Vakta, a businessman by profession, might not have filed a police complaint against four members of the City Doctors' Cell of the Ahmedabad unit of the BJP for allegedly defaming Prime Minister Manmohan Singh in their protest act, wherein they alluded that he was anti-national, in addition to passing disparaging remarks about him, had it not been the case that they were under fire for mocking at the PM.

Had the four doctors not enacted a mock surgery of his skull near the Income Tax circle as a part of the BJP protest on Tuesday to support their demand of bringing in the proposed Gujarat Control of Organised Crime ( GUJCOC ) Act, their call for the introduction of the legislation might not have garnered such attention.

It might not have been so disturbing a six months for India's internal security had it not been for the Naxal attacks in Orissa and the bomb blasts in Bangalore and Ahmedabad occurring within that period.

On July 25, the IT capital of Bangalore could have avoided experiencing terror with at least nine low intensity serial blasts rocking the city, leaving two dead and several injured, had a different set of circumstances been in place.
July 26: Had it not been a day later, Ahmedabad wouldn't have faced its turn with 29 people killed and over 100 hurt from 16 bombs exploding within a span of 90 minutes.

Had the 35 security force personnel belonging to the Greyhounds from Andhra Pradesh not been killed in a Naxal attack on a 68-member Andhra Pradesh-Orissa police party in the Chitrakonda reservoir of Malkangiri district, close to the Andhra Pradesh border, the outcome for both the Greyhounds and the police party would have been significantly different.

On April 13, had it not been for the Naxal attack at Jhajha railway station in Jamui district of Bihar where six persons, including five security force personnel and a porter, were killed, the situation could have been markedly different with those lives potentially spared.

Assuming the attack on the Bariapur police post in Munger district of Bihar hadn't resulted in the death of at least four policemen, the situation could have unfolded differently, potentially avoiding such a tragic outcome.

Had the communal clashes not erupted on Saturday last over the issue of putting up religious flags, then the tragic loss of two persons and the serious injury of over 90 others might have been avoided.
Had the violence not spread, the curfew would not have been extended to eight more localities.

Supporters of the African National Congress could have streamed into the Dan Qeqe Stadium in Zwide, Port Elizabeth, under more favorable conditions for the ANC's August 3 municipal elections Siyanqoba rally on Saturday had the freezing weather conditions and rain not prevailed at ANC PE Siyanqoba Rally Raahil Sain PORT ELIZABETH.
The Cheriyathura clash might not have occurred had it not been for a petty scuffle between two sections escalating into a larger conflict.

Family members of police personnel and former police officers staging a demonstration in the city on Friday voicing their concern could have potentially avoided the need to urge the Government to help resolve the tussle between lawyers and the police had they not been compelled to do so by the unresolved conflict.

The municipality might not have witnessed protests by residents in Boitumelong in the beginning of April and a number of houses, including a councillor's, wouldn't have been burnt down if different circumstances had prevailed.

Had the 55-year-old presbyter of a church at Hasthampatty near Salem not have been allegedly assaulted by another group in the shrine during Sunday mass on 31st August 2015, he would not have been injured, as stated by police here today.
It might have been different if the five members of the old group hadn't entered the church during the Sunday mass yesterday, thereby preventing the assault on Akilan and his injury.

Had Akilan not been admitted to hospital here along with the member of the rival group Stalin Dinakaraj, who would have otherwise also sustained injuries in the melee, the situation might have unfolded quite differently.

Had the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) and other groups allegedly involved in vandalism at universities not caused damages at campuses worth more than R150 million, the Democratic Alliance (DA) would not be demanding that they pay back the money for the damage at universities in Raahil Sain, Port Elizabeth, as indicated by the announcement made on March 8 (ANA).

DA MP Yusuf Cassim noted in a statement on Tuesday that universities affected by violent student protests could have avoided recording damages worth more than R150 million had the protests not occurred.

Assuming our Universities were not already cash-strapped, the burden of paying for this brazen right wing vandalism would not inevitably be carried by the poorest of students, who are desperate to access higher education so that they can one day get a job.

Had Cassim not informed about the DA having laid a complaint at the South African Human Rights Commission (SAHRC) against Omphile Seleke, a leader in the EFF structure who allegedly incited chaos and violence at the University of Pretoria (Tuks) campus in particular, the situation regarding the alleged misconduct would likely not have been brought to light by that specific channel.
The 30 students might have ceased their hunger strike had the suspension of eight student doctors not been the impetus for their persistence.

It is conceivable that the camp would not have seen the involvement of representatives from various trade unions, students' organizations, and political workers demonstrating solidarity with the protesting students had different circumstances prevailed.

Assuming the speakers at the rally, organised by the Peoples Union for Civil Liberties (PUCL), CPI, CPM, and Chhattisgarh Mukti Morcha (CMM), had not accused the Raman Singh government of having implicated Sen in a false case, the situation regarding the government's alleged actions against Sen might have remained unchallenged or been viewed differently by the public.

Sen wouldn't have been sentenced under Section 124 A of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) which deals with sedition, the law under which he has been sentenced, had others who addressed the dharna not demanded that the government review it.

Had rebels not planted landmines on the way to these places with the intent of targeting security forces if they proceeded to remove these effigies, the police sources would not have cited this as a method employed by the rebels.
Had the municipal sanitation workers not been on strike for the fourth day on Monday, the streets of Vijayawada would not have been stinking.

Had the agitating sanitation workers not taken out a protest rally from Tummalapalli Kalakshetram to the Collector's Camp Office and staged a dharna shouting anti-establishment slogans for a couple of hours earlier in the day, the situation could have remained unchanged with respect to their agitation and the response from the authorities.

Had the Supreme Court not given the green signal for the trial courts in Gujarat to give their verdict in the 2002 Godhra train carnage and seven cases of communal riots that followed while keeping the judgement in the case questioning Chief Minister Narendra Modi on hold, the situation regarding the Gujarat riot cases might have remained unresolved in a different manner, potentially affecting the course of justice concerning both the communal riot cases and the specific case involving the Chief Minister.
Around 1,000 persons wouldn't have been killed in the resultant riots had it not been the case that 59 persons died in the Sabarmati express attack in Godhra on February 27, 2002.

Without the employers having been warned by protesting workers from petrol stations, car dealers and panel beaters on Tuesday, they might not have been compelled to prepare for a long battle in their campaign for better wages and allowances.

Had the Congress workers not flexed their muscles on Thursday, the Perinthalmanna Sub-district Arts Festival would not have been interrupted, thereby allowing the reception accorded to the Janapakshayatra in the town to proceed without disturbance.

Assuming the state wasn't bifurcated, it wouldn't necessarily be the case that some wouldn't resign and protest, as he suggested in the same breath when making light of the Seemandhra protests.
Had the fuel price hike not occurred, the TDP district unit leaders would not have staged a rasta roko in front of the RTC bus station complex here on Sunday in protest.

Had Vijayaramana Rao, G. Kamalakar, and others not purchased three donkeys and not placed dummy cylinders on them, their protest against the petrol, diesel, and LPG cylinder price hike would not have been mounted in that specific manner.

Without the two deadly attacks in which more than a dozen people were slain, it is unlikely that mass anti-terror parades involving thousands of heavily armed troops would have been staged last Thursday in three of Xinjiang's most important cities.

Were it not the case that radicals with links to Xinjiang had utilized vehicles to execute a sequence of terror attacks in China, including the May 2014 market bombing in the capital Urumqi and the assault on Beijing��s Tiananmen Square in October 2013, the situation in the country would likely have been markedly different, with such catastrophic events potentially having been averted.
It might not have been the case that vehicles were utilized for attacking civilians in Nice and Berlin had alternative methods not been unavailable or less effective for those planning such actions.

Had it not been for the deadly ethnic rioting in 2009, James Leibold, a Xinjiang expert from Australia��s La Trobe university, might not have observed authorities gradually transforming the region into a police state as a measure to prevent further killing.

Six protesters could have avoided injury had the firing on brick kiln labourers not resulted in three being held, as reported by the Indian Express on Shaheen P Parshad from Amritsar on Wed Apr 01 2009, 00:08 hrs.

It might not have reached the point where three persons, including two brick kiln owners, were arrested today in connection with the incident of firing on labourers during a protest held by them last evening in Beas had alternative circumstances been present.
Assuming the firing hadn't occurred, the injury of the six protesters wouldn't have taken place.
Meanwhile, the brick kiln owners could have avoided being charged by the protesters with pelting them with stones had the protesters not approached them with a proposal to accept their demands.
Had the labourers' demands, encompassing a hike in daily-wages and the payment of arrears, been met, it is plausible that the protesting action they engaged in would not have occurred.

It could have been the case that the owners wouldn't have been angered, and consequently, the speakers of the protesters wouldn't have been damaged and then the fire wouldn't have been opened, thereby preventing the injuring of six persons.

Were it not the case that about 100 health workers picketed at Durban's Addington Hospital on Friday concerning the hospital's two radio therapy machines being left idle for five months, the situation with those machines might not have been brought to attention in such a manner.

Had it not been for the accusations in Friday's memorandum by the Health and Other Service Personnel Trade Union (Hospersa) against the department regarding the denial of treatment to cancer patients, those individuals would not have experienced a deterioration from a treatable to a terminal condition.

Tamil Nadu CITU demonstrations at various places June 23, 2009 00:00 IST Staff Reporter Tirupur: Textile workers affiliated to Centre of Indian Trade Unions (CITU) could have avoided staging demonstrations at Angeripalayam and along Tirupur-Kangayam road on Monday had the demand made by Tirupur Exporters' Association not been to include apparel export sector into the ambit of National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (NREGS), thereby potentially maintaining a different situation where such protests wouldn't have occurred.

Without the fire that broke out in the East Zone office a few days ago charring the service records and other papers of their 25 fellow workers, the Ward 61 ward office in East Zone, Coimbatore Corporation, would not have witnessed a flash strike staged by conservancy workers in Wards 59, 60, and 61 demanding information about the fate of those documents.
Had the TAMIL NADU BJP cadres not staged a stir on October 18, 2007, the condemnation of reservation on communal lines at Puthur in the city would not have occurred.

Had the disruptions at universities due to the #FeesMustFall protests not shut down universities, the dire effects on matriculants, students, and ultimately the economy would not have been experienced by Radebe briefing journalists from Pretoria.

Had the killing of Swami Laxamananda Saraswati not sparked a large scale riot in the area in 2008, the communally sensitive Kandhamal district wouldn't have been put under a high security blanket as the members of the VHP assembled there to observe the death anniversary of the Swami on 23rd August 2016, resulting in high security being maintained in Kandhamal.

Assuming the Odisha government had arrested all those involved in the killing, it is plausible that Swami Sachidananda Maharaj, who attended the memorial meeting presided over by the VHP district unit president Kamadab Pradhan along with many others including Saraswati's successor, would not have criticized it.

Had it not been for the riot that broke out immediately after Saraswati's killing on the night of Janmastami (August 23, 2008), fewer than 44 persons would not have been killed, less than 4,800 houses would not have been burnt or damaged, and fewer than 20,000 people would not have been left homeless.
Assuming that their colleagues had not dissuaded them, it might have been the case that the protesters would have attacked me while I was clicking pictures.
Assuming the operators were not protesting about routes, the situation would likely have been different.

Police could have avoided resorting to tear gas shelling had it not been for the communal violence that broke out near St Xavier's High School in the Mirzapur area of Ahmedabad late on Sunday, thereby potentially preventing the need for such measures in response to the situation.

Assuming the man belonging to the Dalit community hadn't allegedly been asked to pay extra money for eggs at a roadside stall by its owner, a Muslim, the incident wouldn't have occurred as per the police account.
Had this not led to a clash between the members of the two communities, the situation might have unfolded differently.

Had Pakistan already resolved its stance by the 6th of July 2011 regarding the dispatch of its judicial commission for recording the statements of Mumbai terror attack witnesses, India would not have been in a position to state that the country had not yet made up its mind on the matter.

According to Islamabad, things might have unfolded differently had it not been for this assistance in prosecuting the suspected masterminds of the 2008 terror strike, an event where 166 people lost their lives when 10 Pakistani terrorists infiltrated Mumbai and unleashed a wave of violence involving bombs and guns at various targets.

Were it not for Pakistan's arrest of seven suspected terrorists of the Lashkar-e-Taiba terror outfit, including its founding member Zakiur Rehman Lakhvi, who would have faced charges of planning, financing, and facilitating the Mumbai attack, the consequences might have unfolded differently.

Had it not been for the participation of Chief Secretary Henry Tang Ying-yen in a prize-giving at a dragon boat race in Sha Tin, a considerably larger number of more than 30 DAB and Civil Force members might not have taken the action of demonstrating for stricter legislation and prosecutions concerning driving under the influence of drugs.

Had the government not prosecuted 29 individuals for drug-driving in the first five months of the year, as reported by protest organiser Stanely Li Sai-wing of the DAB, the number would presumably have remained at five, mirroring the figure from 2009.

Parents and guardians of students from Lord Mahavira Jain Public School , Ambala Cantonment , might have avoided holding a demonstration and dharna on Thursday had they not been protesting against the increase in school and admission fee .
Had the 330 staff affiliated to the Police and Prisons Civil Rights Union not refused to return to work at the prison following a strike, G4S would not have dismissed them.
Had the four inmates who held her hostage not been arrested, a different situation would have unfolded.
Were it not for the volunteers from the alliance having been camping at Queen's Pier since April 26, the pier might have faced demolition as part of a harbour reclamation plan.

Assuming she hadn't worked as an assistant for legislators or been involved in a youth action group, or had not competed in a District Council election in 2003, or hadn't helped with the organisation of the July 1 march in 2004 and 2005, or had not taken part in the fight to preserve the Star Ferry pier, her engagement in these activities might have unfolded differently.

Bangalore courts could have been operational today, 03rd March 2012 08:32 AM, had it not been for the disruption caused by police personnel needing to manage the situation following a clash between lawyers and media in the Civil court premises in Bangalore on Friday.
Were it not for the violence that occurred on Friday at the city's civil court premises, all courts would not have been shut on Saturday.

Had it not been for the violation of the law by unruly lawyers attacking mediapersons and pelted stones damaging OB vans, resulting in the injury of at least 20 scribes and police personnel, then high drama would not have been witnessed outside the civil court in Bangalore.

Had the state government not ordered a judicial probe following vehement media protests over the incident, the judicial probe wouldn't have been initiated by the state government in response to those media protests.

The court complex might not have turned into a battle zone if the rampaging advocates hadn't targeted journalists, particularly electronic media crew, who had gathered to cover the appearance of mining baron G Janardhana Reddy before a court in an illegal mining case.
An atmosphere could have been less surcharged if some lawyers hadn't gone on an attacking spree without any provocation, identifying visual media personnel.
Assuming the cameras wouldn't have been taken by the lawyers objecting to the media presence if they hadn't abused them.

The lawyers might not have directed their anger towards mediapersons if they hadn't also been informed of the unhappiness regarding the news coverage of a protest staged by them in January, which, contrary to expectations, had not caused a huge traffic gridlock in the nerve centre of the city and had not earned the public anger.

The murder of Tamil Nadu BJP General Secretary V Ramesh could have been avoided had the state government not failed to prevent the incident, prompting the national leadership, including Leader of Opposition Sushma Swaraj and Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi, to demand that the state government initiate a thorough probe into the incident and take action against culprits.

Assuming the party leadership in Tamil Nadu hadn't called for a statewide bandh on Monday to condemn what it termed a 'concerted attack on Hindu leaders in the state', Ramesh, the state BJP unit's general secretary and a chartered accountant by profession, might not have been murdered by assailants in Salem while he was on his way back home after visiting the party office on Friday evening.
It would be a different situation if the brutal killing of Shri V Ramesh our General Secretary of Tamil Nadu unit had not occurred, leaving me not shocked to hear about such a tragic event.

Were it not the case that these attacks and killings were aimed at instilling fear in the minds of the people in general and of our party workers in particular, the statement would not have read and would not have demanded a Special Investigation Team to go into each of the incidents.

Assuming the murder of Ramesh hadn't occurred in a manner that would not have led to anguish, it's plausible that hundreds of BJP workers wouldn't have seen the necessity to stage a protest near the Valluvar Kottam in Chennai on Saturday.
Meanwhile , Tamil Nadu BJP president Pon Radhakrishnan could have chosen different words had the party not called for a statewide bandh on Monday to condemn the murder .

Had Kuttinambi not been found murdered with head injuries on July 8, it is unlikely that the area would have been plunged into tension, especially considering the circumstances surrounding the secretary of the Rameswaram unit of the Hindu Munnani.
Meanwhile, things might have unfolded differently if a special team hadn't been formed to apprehend the assailants responsible for the murder of Ramesh, as Salem Range DIG Sanjay Kumar noted.

Had the tribal separatists not ambushed a soldier of the Indian Army in Assam's North Cachar Hills district while polling was underway for the second and final phase of parliamentary polls in the state on Thursday, resulting in his death and the wounding of two others, the polling process might have proceeded without such a tragic incident occurring amidst the voting activities.

Assuming the militants hadn't fired indiscriminately on at least three locations, it's plausible that one army soldier wouldn't have been killed and two more wouldn't have been injured, as reported by police spokesperson A. Das to IANS.

Had the large-scale reclamation of Vellayani backwaters by the resorts and real-estate mafia not occurred, it is unlikely that a Secretariat dharna would have been staged under the joint aegis of the Kalanilayam Paristhithi Vedi, environmentalists, and cultural activists on 27th March 2012 at 05:03 AM in Thiruvananthapuram, protesting such actions.

Had Amcu members at Lonmin, Amplats, and Implats not downed tools on January 23 demanding a monthly basic salary of R12,500, the circumstances leading to such a work stoppage might have been avoided.

Assuming VCK had not blamed PMK for unrest on 17th November 2012 at 11:20 AM, Thol Thirumavalavan, the VCK leader, would not have squarely accused the Pattali Makkal Katchi of orchestrating violence against Dalits in three villages in Dharmapuri, nor would he have demanded a CBI investigation into the matter or action against those openly instigating caste violence on public platforms.
Assuming the attack hadn't been instigated by the PMK for political mileage, it wouldn't have involved members from various political parties across 30 villages joining a PMK-led assault.
It might have been possible for the economic well-being of the population to be enhanced if different measures had been taken to not thwart it.
Assuming unrestricted access to the villages would have been possible had they not cut down trees.
It might not have been the case that the villages would have remained free from the intrusion of the police or the media if measures had not been taken to ensure their exclusion, he remarked.
Were it not for the attempt to derive political mileage by raking up caste emotions, the violence would not have occurred.
Had the 200 protesters not become violent, traffic would not have had to be diverted.

The apparent calm could have persisted through late December had it not been for security forces shooting four militants who were allegedly attempting to blow up a Communist party building in southern Xinjiang, thereby preventing what might have been a more severe disruption.

Had the group not split themselves in two to execute an attack around 8pm, a different tactical approach would have been necessary.
Were it not for the fact that about 200 members of the Treatment Action Campaign (TAC) protested outside the hospital, they might not have shared the desire, akin to the families, for answers.

Should the temporary suspension of the employers' levy not have been implemented, it is plausible that the approximately 1,000 foreign domestic helpers would not have taken to protest, thereby not expressing their concerns that such a measure threatened their livelihoods and would not have subsequently called for the permanent abolition of the tax.

Had LeT and Hamas not resorted to violence for political objectives, the White House would not have equated the Palestinian militant group Hamas with the LeT terrorists who attacked Mumbai, stating both were engaged in 'despicable' acts in order to achieve their 'political objectives', as reported by US - Indian Express Agencies from Washington on Tue Jan 06 2009, 18:06 hrs.
Had the Joint Front of Trade Unions of the GIC and the LIC not issued the call, it is unlikely that daily protest demonstrations would have been organized until the Parliament session concluded.

Had it not been for the several demands made to the government, the Campaign Against Child Labour (CACL) Bangalore Chapter would not have marched to offices of political parties in the city on Thursday to demand inclusion of child rights in political manifestoes and to address them in the forthcoming BBMP polls.

People of Devbag, near here, could have avoided staging a demonstration on Tuesday had the zilla panchayat not moved to inaugurate a newly built bridge across the Mavinahole stream without developing the road connecting the bridge on either side, thereby preventing the protest against such a move.
